Problem:
Consider a continuous-time system governed by the linear partial differential equation \\(\\partial_t u = Lu\\), where L is a linear differential operator. The effect of applying a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\), to the initial condition \\(u_0\\) of \\(u(t,x)\\), followed by its evolution in time is analyzed.

If a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}(u_0)\\) is applied to the initial condition \\(u_0\\) at t = 0, followed by the normal evolution of the system under \\(\\partial_t u = Lu\\) without any further intervention, will the state of \\(u(t,x)\\) at any time t be the same as directly evolving \\(u_0\\) under \\(\\partial_t u = Lu\\)?
Explanation: Applying the Fourier transform to \\(u_0\\) changes its initial state in the frequency domain, potentially altering how the system responds to the operator L. The evolution of this transformed state under \\(\\partial_t u = Lu\\) results in a solution which may substantially differ due to changes in initial frequency components and their respective diffusions or propagations.
